title: What AI means for your product strategy | Paul Adams (CPO of Intercom)
key_insights: Hire your first PM when you have 8-10 engineers, ideally promoting an internal analyst, engineer, or designer who understands company culture
Target mid-stage companies (300-500 people) that have reached product-market-channel fit for optimal career growth
When hiring leaders, look at best-in-class companies in your space and recruit the lieutenants, not the top leaders
Founders should spend 2 hours daily on hiring: 1 hour on outreach, 1 hour on candidate conversations
Delay giving director and VP titles as long as possible to avoid organizational constraints and title inflation
40-50% of new customers should come from organic channels, not just paid acquisition
Angel investing should be founder-centric rather than market-centric, focusing on authentic problem-solving motivation
topics_discussed: Career path from networking aspirations to Google AdSense PM
When and how to hire your first product manager
Product development processes at different company stages
Common pitfalls in early-stage product development
Hiring strategies and company evaluation criteria
Angel investing approach and deal sourcing
Building personal brand for investment opportunities
Board member perspectives on crypto and fintech
Company culture differences across tech giants
memorable_quotes: Great careers are built by knowing a lot of people doing great work so they know and want you on their teams, and just waiting for serendipity and then seizing it and jumping.
A bad PM can really screw up the work of 10 engineers. So it's much more important to hire good PM than it is to hire a good engineer.
I would much rather be the number two or number three person at the leader in a space, than the top person at a second-tier company.
frameworks_mentioned: Weekly to quarterly planning progression framework
8-10 engineer threshold for first PM hire
2 hours daily hiring time allocation (1 hour outreach, 1 hour meetings)
40-50% organic vs paid customer acquisition ratio
recommended_for: Product managers at various career stages
Leaders building product and engineering teams
summary: Gokul Rajaram shares battle-tested insights on building product teams, hiring strategies, and angel investing, drawing from his experience at Google, Facebook, Square, and DoorDash. The conversation provides tactical frameworks for startup founders on when to hire PMs, how to structure organizations, and the importance of serendipity in career development.
